coredata.dc:title: ETPTA polymer network confined amide-based eutectic electrolyte for safe and long- life lithium metal battery

coredata.dc:description: Serious safety issues and uncontrollable lithium dendrites hinder the commercial application of high-voltage lithium metal batteries (LMBs) that employ carbonate-based electrolytes. Herein, we propose a eutectogel electrolyte, an amide-based eutectic electrolyte consisting of lithium bis (trifluoromethyl sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) and N-methyl-2,2,2-trifluoroacetamide (3F-NMA) confined by trimethylolpropane ethoxylate triacrylate (ETPTA) polymer network. Compared with the carbonate-based electrolyte, the non-flammable eutectogel electrolyte facilitates the formation of LiF/LixN-rich solid electrolyte interfaces, therefore expands the electrochemical window, enhances the interfacial compatibility, and improves the cycling stability of LMB. Besides, it shows a high lithium-ion transference number of 0.63 and a stable long-term lithium stripping/plating (>2300 h) in a Li||Li symmetric cell, at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2. Additionally, the Li||LiFePO4 full cell with eutectogel electrolyte exhibits a commendable cycling stability, achieving a capacity retention of 77.4 % after 1000 cycles at 5 C (30 °C) and maintaining 82 % capacity following 400 cycles at 1 C (60 °C). When used as the electrolyte in Li||LiCoO2 full cell, it renders the battery appealing performance including a notable initial discharge capacity of 170.3 mAh g−1 and a retained capacity of 86.3 % after 300 cycles, at a high charge voltage of 4.45 V. This research may provide insight into the design of eutectogel electrolytes for high-performance lithium metal batteries.

head.ce:title: ETPTA polymer network confined amide-based eutectic electrolyte for safe and long- life lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Herein, we propose a eutectogel electrolyte, an amide-based eutectic electrolyte consisting of lithium bis (trifluoromethyl sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) and N-methyl-2,2,2-trifluoroacetamide (3F-NMA) confined by trimethylolpropane ethoxylate triacrylate (ETPTA) polymer network, which facilitates the formation of stable LiF/LixN-rich solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI), ensures prolonged cycle performance of batteries. Overall, compared with the commercial electrolyte, the eutectogel electrolyte shows better thermal stability and safety, exhibits better electrochemical performance, and maintains superior cycling stability at high temperature and high voltage.

Serious safety issues and uncontrollable lithium dendrites hinder the commercial application of high-voltage lithium metal batteries (LMBs) that employ carbonate-based electrolytes. Herein, we propose a eutectogel electrolyte, an amide-based eutectic electrolyte consisting of lithium bis (trifluoromethyl sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) and N-methyl-2,2,2-trifluoroacetamide (3F-NMA) confined by trimethylolpropane ethoxylate triacrylate (ETPTA) polymer network. Compared with the carbonate-based electrolyte, the non-flammable eutectogel electrolyte facilitates the formation of LiF/LixN-rich solid electrolyte interfaces, therefore expands the electrochemical window, enhances the interfacial compatibility, and improves the cycling stability of LMB. Besides, it shows a high lithium-ion transference number of 0.63 and a stable long-term lithium stripping/plating (>2300 h) in a Li||Li symmetric cell, at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2. Additionally, the Li||LiFePO4 full cell with eutectogel electrolyte exhibits a commendable cycling stability, achieving a capacity retention of 77.4 % after 1000 cycles at 5 C (30 °C) and maintaining 82 % capacity following 400 cycles at 1 C (60 °C). When used as the electrolyte in Li||LiCoO2 full cell, it renders the battery appealing performance including a notable initial discharge capacity of 170.3 mAh g−1 and a retained capacity of 86.3 % after 300 cycles, at a high charge voltage of 4.45 V. This research may provide insight into the design of eutectogel electrolytes for high-performance lithium metal batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium is considered a promising anode for rechargeable metal batteries because of its high specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and low voltage (−3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) [1–4]. However, the utilization of lithium metal anode is currently plagued by the growth of lithium dendrites during the charge/discharge cycling [5]. Generally, when assembled with carbonate-based electrolytes, solid electrolyte interfaces (SEIs) with high organic contents and lithophilicity are generated, which vigorously encourage the vertical formation of lithium dendrites [6–9]. Due to the high reactivity, lithium dendrites constantly consume lithium anode and electrolyte, reducing battery life [10]. The continuous accumulation of dendrites may also lead to separator puncturing, thereby causing a short circuit in battery and presenting a significant safety hazard [11]. These problems become more prominent at high current densities. In this regard, ether-based electrolytes are considered as a kind of alternative electrolytes, due to the better compatibility with lithium anode [12]. Regrettably, most of the ether-based solvents demonstrate oxidative stability under 4 V, which fails to satisfy the demands of high-voltage cathodes rated at 4.45 V or higher. As a result, these solvents are not appropriate for high-energy–density LMBs [13,14]. Moreover, both carbonate and ether solvents have high volatility and flammability, making them susceptible to fire or explosion under extreme conditions [15]. Therefore, the development of non-flammable electrolytes that guarantee high interfacial stability for both high-voltage cathode and lithium-metal anode is urgently needed for LMBs [16].

Recently, many nonflammable electrolytes for LMBs have been proposed, including perfluorinated electrolytes, ionic liquid-based electrolytes, deep eutectic solvent (DES) electrolytes, as well as all-solid and quasi-solid electrolytes [17,18]. Among these electrolytes, DES electrolytes have drawn great attention due to advantages such as low vapor pressure, non-flammability, broad electrochemical window, designability, and simplicity of manufacture [19]. However, because of the liquid character of DES electrolytes, the safety risk of electrolyte leakage cannot be eliminated [20]. Besides, the electrolyte depletion and dendrite growth associated with the side-reaction of DES electrolytes with lithium metal often result in poor reversibility of LMBs. In comparison, solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) can effectively avoid the issue of electrolyte leakage [21]. Their inherent advantages, such as light weight, high mechanical strength and easy machinability, are also attractive [22–25]. Nonetheless, the implementation of SPEs in LMBs still encounters specific constraints, particularly in conjunction with lithium-metal anodes. This combination frequently results in diminished ionic conductivity and inadequate interfacial chemical stability [26–28]. Therefore, it is essential to develop advanced SPEs that exhibit high ionic conductivity, outstanding interfacial stability, and a wide voltage stabilization range [29,30]. In assessing the advantages and disadvantages of eutectic electrolytes versus polymer electrolytes, it is logical to consider that the combination of deep eutectic solvents with polymer electrolytes could lead to the creation of non-flammable electrolytes. This would provide a broader electrochemical window and improved electrochemical performance for LMBs. Nevertheless, research in this area remains insufficient, and further exploration of eutectic-based polymer electrolytes with superior performance is necessary.

This work presents the synthesis and characterization of a novel eutectogel electrolyte. The electrolyte comprises LiTFSI and 3F-NMA in a 1:5 eutectic ratio, fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as an additive, trimethylolpropane ethoxylate triacrylate (ETPTA) as a polymerization monomer, and azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator. The synthesis utilizes an in-situ thermally initiated polymerization method. Theoretical calculations indicate that the design of the polymer system enhances the high-voltage stability of the electrolyte. Characterizations suggest that the eutectogel electrolyte favors the formation of a robust fluorine-rich and nitrogen-rich SEI and cathodic electrolyte interface (CEI), which inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites and enhance the compatibility between electrolyte and electrode. Lithium symmetric cells based on the eutectogel electrolyte enable long-term stable lithium stripping/plating. Moreover, Li||LiFePO4 utilizing the eutectogel electrolyte demonstrates outstanding cycling performance at both ambient and elevated temperatures. In addition, the electrolyte has been successfully applied in Li||LCoO2 (4.45 V) cells, demonstrating its potential for application in high-voltage LMBs. This work offers valuable insights into the capabilities of eutectogel electrolytes for the development of high-performance LMBs.

To determine the optimal content of lithium salt, we prepared DES solutions with different molar ratios (LiTFSI to 3F-NMA for 1:4/5/6) and carried out EIS and LSV tests with them. It can be seen in Fig. S1 and Table S1 that the ionic conductivity increases and the electrochemical stabilization window narrows as the lithium salt concentration decreases. At a eutectic ratio of 1:5, the DES solution shows moderate ionic conductivity and electrochemical stabilization window. Therefore, this ratio was selected for subsequent study. Fig. 1 shows the synthesis of eutectogel electrolyte. Briefly, a precursor solution containing 2 mmol LiTFSI, 10 mmol 3F-NMA, 6 wt% ETPTA, 11.62 mg AIBN initiator, and FEC additive (5 wt%) were firstly prepared, then underwent a polymerization at 70 °C to get a transparent gel (Fig. S2). The FTIR spectra of the ETPTA monomer and the prepared eutectogel electrolyte are shown in Fig. 2 a. The peak observed at 1631 cm−1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of the CC bond in ETPTA, which is absent in the FTIR spectrum of eutectogel electrolyte after [31]. Hence, it can be concluded that after being heated to 70 °C, ETPTA successfully underwent polymerization with AIBN serving as the initiator [32,33]. The melting points of the eutectogel electrolyte and the eutectic electrolyte (1:5) were recorded at 8.12 °C and 2.59 °C, respectively, using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (Fig. 2b and S3). In comparison, the melting points of the individual components exceed the eutectogel/eutectic electrolytes (Tm (LiTFSI) = 236 °C, Tm (3F-NMA) = 50 °C, Tm (FEC) = 18–23 °C). According to the Lewis acid-base definition, Li+ is a Lewis acid and can form DES with 3F-NMA containing Lewis basic (−CO) groups. The reduced melting point, together with the above changed FTIR profiles, confirms the successful polymerization [34,35].

The ionic conductivity of the eutectogel electrolyte and commercial electrolyte (1 M LiPF6 in EC: DEC, 1:1 by vol) were assessed using temperature-dependent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in the range of 30 °C to 70 °C. As illustrated in Fig. 2c, in the curves that represent the two electrolytes, the logarithm of ionic conductivity and 1/T displays a typical linear correlation. Also, the ionic conductivity of the two electrolytes shows a gradual increase in conductivity as the temperature rises. Based on the Arrhenius equation, the activation energies for ionic transport in the commercial and eutectogel electrolytes were determined to be 0.12 eV and 0.21 eV, respectively. This finding aligns with the ionic conductivity trends shown in Fig. S4 and Table S1. Table S2 summarizes the ionic conductivities of some recently reported polymer electrolytes and the present eutectogel electrolyte. It shows that the eutectogel electrolyte shows a higher ionic conductivity than many polymer electrolytes. However, due to its gel state, the ionic conductivity has a certain gap with commercial liquid electrolyte (0.75 vs. 4.22 mS cm−1). Fig. 2d shows the time–current curve of DC polarization and the EIS profiles of batteries at initial and steady states. The calculated lithium-ion transference number (tLi +) for eutectogel electrolyte is 0.63, suggesting that lithium ions can be transferred rapidly in the proposed eutectogel electrolyte. By contrast, the liquid commercial electrolyte has a higher lithium-ion transference number (0.69, Fig. S5). The transference number of the eutectogel electrolyte is slightly lower than the liquid commercial electrolyte, agreeing well with its relatively low ionic conductivity. This is because the flow characteristics of liquid electrolyte facilitates the ion migration. Nevertheless, it is noted that the transference number of the present eutectogel electrolyte is still competitive among the reported polymer electrolytes, as summarized in Table S3.

It is known that the oxidative stability of electrolytes is of paramount importance for its utilization. To evaluate the oxidative stability, the asymmetric Li||SS (stainless steel) cells utilizing the eutectogel electrolyte and the commercial electrolyte were analyzed by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. As illustrated in Fig. 2e, the eutectogel electrolyte exhibits a significantly higher oxidation potential of 5.3 V than the commercial electrolyte (4.4 V), suggesting that the eutectogel electrolyte can provide a wider electrochemical stability window than the commercial counterpart. Subsequently, the oxidative stability of ETPTA was verified by DFT theoretical calculations. The oxidative stability of a model polymer fragment containing three monomer units (denoted as ETPTA3) was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 2g, after interacting with Li+, the energy of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) reduced from −5.58 eV to −7.78 eV, demonstrating the excellent high-voltage stability of the eutectogel electrolyte [36,37]. Although the HOMO energy level of polymerized ETPTA3 is higher than ETPTA, its antioxidant property is enhanced after interacting with Li+ (from −5.50 eV to −6.81 eV). This aligns with previous findings, demonstrating that the molecular architecture of polymers can significantly improve the electrochemical window, serving as a valuable benchmark for advancing high-energy density solid-state batteries [38,39]. Combustion tests showed that the eutectogel electrolyte is non-flammable, whereas the commercial electrolyte is highly flammable (Fig. 2f). Thermogravimetric analysis revealed that the commercial electrolyte decomposed severely at 100°C, whereas only a small amount of free solvent evaporated from the eutectogel electrolyte (Fig. S6). The above results suggest that the thermal stability of the eutectogel electrolyte is superior to the commercial electrolyte, which ensures the safe operation of batteries.

DFT calculations were used to evaluate the affinity between Li+ and solvent molecules/polymers [40]. The distribution of electron density around each component can be seen from the electrostatic potential distribution (Fig. 3 a). The oxygen atoms in TFSI−, 3F-NMA, ETPTA3 and FEC molecules have high charge density and are easily coordinated with Li+. Compared with Li-3F-NMA (−2.93 eV) and Li-FEC (−2.84 eV), Li-TFSI− (−6.85 eV) and Li-ETPTA3 (−5.50 eV) have higher interaction energies (Fig. 3c), implying that Li+ is more readily bounded with TFSI− and has significant interactions with the ETPTA network. Fig. 3c implies that the interaction between Li+ and ETPTA3 is stronger than the interaction between Li+ and ETPTA monomer, which may cause a slower migration of lithium ions. However, the appreciable ionic conductivity and lithium-ion transference number at 4.22 mS cm−1 and 0.63 suggest that the ETPTA network can still ensure the rapid migration of Li+ and therefore facilitate the uniform deposition of Li+ [41–43]. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were also performed to provide theoretical insight into the specific structure of the eutectogel electrolyte. Fig. 3d displays the MD simulation box, which defines the solvation environment of Li+ within the eutectogel electrolyte. The corresponding radial distribution functions (RDFs) and coordination numbers (CNs) of the compositional molecules were also analyzed (Fig. 3e). The prominent peaks of Li-O pairs at ∼2 Å away from Li+ in Fig. 3e correspond to the TFSI−, 3F-NMA, ETPTA3 and FEC molecules in the primary solvation shell, while the minor peaks at around 4 Å imply the molecules in the secondary solvation shell at small portions. Although all the composition molecules show similar RDFs profiles, their spatial arrangements in solvation shells may vary since factors such as the different coordination affinity, the multidentate ligation and the number of molecules are known to bring about varied solvation structures [44]. As seen in Fig. 3e, the sharp peaks of Li-O pairs for TFSI− and 3F-NMA appear at 1.89 and 1.97 Å, and the average CNs are 1.84 and 2.57, respectively. As for ETPTA3, the sharp peak of Li-O pair is observed at 1.87 Å, with a CN of 0.16. For FEC, the sharp peak of Li-O pair is seen at 1.92 Å, with a CN of 0.23. These results suggest that the transport of Li+ is accomplished through the synergy of all component molecules in the eutectogel electrolyte, specifically, via the interaction between Li+ and the CO groups [40,45,46]. Incorporating the previous analysis, the partially solvated structure of the eutectogel electrolyte is proposed. As depicted in Fig. 3f, the first solvation sheath of Li+ includes 5 coordinated oxygen atoms, provided by 1–2 TFSI−, 2–3 3F-NMA, 0–1 ETPTA3 and 0–1 FEC ions/molecules, respectively. Whereas the second solvation shell of Li+ consists of 4 TFSI− and 1 FEC. In addition, some free 3F-NMA molecules exist in the eutectogel.

In order to ascertain the compatibility between the electrolyte and lithium metal, Li||Li symmetric cells were assembled. The investigations were carried out at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2, with a fixed capacity of 0.2 mAh cm−2. Fig. 4 a demonstrates that the eutectogel electrolyte renders the Li||Li symmetric cell a long and stable cycling for 2300 h, significantly outperforming the commercial electrolyte (430 h). When tested at a higher current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 with a fixed capacity of 0.5 mAh cm−2, the eutectogel-based cell demonstrates a stable cycling for 720 h, whereas the battery utilizing the commercial electrolyte exhibits a much shorter lifespan of 340 h (Fig. 4b). Furthermore, the eutectogel electrolyte shows insignificant changes in polarization voltage throughout the cycling process (insets in Fig. 4a and b), highlighting its excellent compatibility with lithium metal. Additionally, Li||Cu asymmetric cells with the above two electrolytes were used to study the lithium stripping/plating efficiencies. As illustrated in Fig. 4c, the mean coulombic efficiency (CE) of the eutectogel-based Li||Cu cell was 92.6 %, which is higher than the commercial electrolyte-based one (89.2 %). The higher CE predicts enhanced cycling stability, improved compatibility with lithium, and greater utilization of lithium anode. The critical current density of the eutectogel electrolyte was measured, reaching a maximum value of 1.9 mA cm−2 (see Fig. 4d). This result indicates the effective dendrite inhibition capability and high interfacial stability of the as-prepared eutectogel electrolyte [47].

To examine lithium deposition morphology, we employed in situ optical microscopy (OM) to monitor the Li+ deposition at a current density of 1 mA cm−2. Fig. 4e illustrates that lithium dendrites emerged on the lithium metal surface after 10 min of deposition in the commercial electrolyte. This occurrence intensified over time, revealing a heterogeneous lithium deposition in this case. Conversely, almost no dendrites were detected in the eutectogel electrolyte after 1 h, indicating that this electrolyte promotes uniform Li+ deposition. The surface morphology of lithium anodes that cycled in Li||Li symmetric cells for both electrolytes was also studied with scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The insets in Fig. S7 reveal the lithium metal surface following electrolyte cycling, indicating that the lithium metal interfacing with the commercial electrolyte exhibits dark, inactive lithium, while the associated SEM image (Fig. S7a) demonstrates a coarse texture, implying irregular lithium deposition. In contrast, the digital photo of the lithium metal interacting with the eutectogel electrolyte displays a smooth lithium surface with a metallic sheen, and the accompanying SEM image (Fig. S7b) shows a compact Li deposition surface.

The compositions of the interfacial layers on Li anodes after 100 cycles in different electrolytes were elucidated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization. As illustrated in Fig. 4f–h, after cycling in the eutectogel electrolyte, the C-F peak (687.5 eV) is seen in the C 1s spectrum, which mainly originates from the decomposition of lithium salt and 3F-NMA [36]. The LiF signal (683.6 eV) is seen in the F 1s spectrum, mainly because the reduction of FEC and lithium salt. The LixN peak also appears at 398.3 eV in the N 1s spectrum, which originates from the decomposition of 3F-NMA and TFSI−. These results suggest that the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film formed in the eutectogel electrolyte is F-rich (LiF) and N-rich (LixN). LiF is excellent electronic insulator with good mechanical property, thus can effectively adjust the flatness of lithium deposition and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. LixN has high ionic conductivity and ensures the rapid transport of Li+ [48]. Therefore, the LiF and LixN components can promote the uniform deposition of Li+ synergically and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. By contrast, the SEI film in the commercial electrolyte mainly consists of CO, CO and PF containing species, which correspond to the reduction products of carbonates and LiPF6. Such interfacial film exhibits brittleness/inhomogeneity and hampers the uniform deposition of Li+, thus leading to inferior cycling performance of battery [2,49].

EIS tests were conducted on the Li||Li symmetric cells following different cycles, as illustrated in Fig. S8. The Li||Li symmetric cell with the commercial electrolyte was short-circuited after 200 cycles, whereas its counterpart battery with eutectogel electrolyte demonstrated remarkably high cycling stability with minimal variation in the total resistance within 500 cycles. Such extended cycling stability of Li||Li symmetric cell can be attributed to the formation of a LiF/LixN-rich SEI layer in the presence of eutectogel electrolyte. This layer diminishes the interfacial side reactions, facilitates the stable diffusion and deposition of Li+, and prevents the formation of lithium dendrite, thereby ensuring the reversibility of lithium stripping and plating [50].

Li||LiFePO4 (LFP) full cells were further assembled and studied at 1 C/5 C, to confirm the advantage of eutectogel electrolyte over the commercial one. Prior to the full cell tests, two activation cycles at 0.1 C were adopted. The initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) was obtained based on data from the first activation cycle. As shown in Fig. 5 a and d, it is seen that the eutectogel-based Li||LFP full cell operates reliably at 1 C with an ICE of 97.0 %, exhibiting a capacity retention of 77.5 % after 800 cycles, with an average CE of 99.8 %. By contrast, the Li||LFP cell with commercial electrolyte shows only 46.6 % capacity retention after 200 cycles, despite exhibiting a higher ICE value of 99.9 % (Fig. 5c). The eutectogel electrolyte also demonstrates superior performance at a higher charge/discharge rate of 5 C. As illustrated in Fig. 5b, the eutectogel-based Li||LFP cell maintains a capacity of 77.4 % and reaches an average CE of 99.9 % after 1,000 cycles. In contrast, the capacity retention of the cell based on commercial electrolyte falls to 22.9 % after only 180 cycles. These results suggest that the eutectogel electrolyte significantly surpasses the commercial electrolyte in terms of cycling stability. Noteworthily, the performance of the present eutectogel electrolyte is also quite highly competitive, when compared with the previously reported polymer-based electrolytes (Table S4). Furthermore, we added two comparison groups for Li||LFP full cells, i.e., 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DEC (1:1 by vol) with 5 % FEC (denoted as CE + 5 % FEC) and eutectogel without FEC (gel-without FEC), and tested the long-cycling performance at 1 C/5 C. As shown in Fig. S9, the cycling performance of gel-without FEC significantly lags behind the eutectogel electrolyte at both current densities. Additionally, the discharge specific capacity of CE + 5 % FEC is inferior to the eutectogel electrolyte at 1 C, despite demonstrating stable cycling. At 5 C, the capacity retention rate of the CE + 5 % FEC-based cell is 74.7 % after only 450 cycles, while the eutectogel electrolyte can reach 77.4 % capacity retention rate after 1000 cycles. It is further demonstrated that the eutectogel electrolyte ensures superior long cycling stability.

Fig. 5e and f show the rate performance and associated charge/discharge profiles of Li||LFP cells at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C (1 C = 170 mAg−1), where the performance of eutectogel electrolyte and commercial electrolyte varies slightly. The specific capacities of the eutectogel electrolyte at different rates were 163, 160, 152, 140, 121, and 82 mAh g−1, respectively. Notably, a peak capacity of 161 mAh g−1 emerged when the current density returned to 0.1 C, indicating the robust capacity reversibility. In contrast, the specific capacity of the commercial electrolyte decreased when the current density returned to 0.1 C, suggesting that it was not as reversible as eutectogel electrolyte. The reversibility of Li||LFP full cells was also studied with cyclic voltammetric (CV) experiments. As illustrated in Fig. 5g and Fig. S10, a distinct pair of peaks at approximately 3.62 V and 3.25 V were observed, corresponding to the redox of Fe2+/Fe3+ within the LFP cathode [51]. Besides, the intensities of the redox peaks in the second scan increase slightly compared with the values in the first scan, when using the eutectogel as the electrolyte, suggesting that the reaction kinetics is accelerated after the formation of interfacial layers during the first scan [6]. Moreover, the curves from the second to fifth scans almost overlap, demonstrating the good reversibility of the battery. In contrast, the CV curves of the commercial electrolyte-based Li||LFP cell exhibit considerable discrepancies during the initial five cycles (Fig. S10), showing a decreasing trend of peak intensities. This indicates that the formation of interfacial layers is insufficient, which leads to diminished electrochemical stability and reversibility.

To further understand the above data, the morphology and composition of the LFP cathode from the post-cycled Li||LFP cells were analyzed. As illustrated in Fig. S11, the surface of LFP cathode after 100 cycles in commercial electrolyte becomes rougher and shows more cracks. While the surface of post-cycled LFP cathode in the eutectogel electrolyte remains smooth with few cracks. The morphology deterioration of LFP cathode cycled in commercial electrolyte may due to the formation of instable interfacial film, along with the buildup of decomposition by-products from the commercial electrolyte [52]. The accumulation of by-products would also hinder the diffusion of Li+ and result in increased interfacial resistance, therefore leading to reduced cell reversibility. By contrast, the eutectogel electrolyte generates more stable cathode/electrolyte interface and ensures more uniform deposition of lithium ions. The interfacial layer on the LFP cathode was further characterized by FIB/SEM. As is shown in Fig. 6 a and b, the cathode-electrolyte interphase (CEI) film developed in the eutectogel electrolyte exhibits a thinner and more uniform structure compared with the film formed in the commercial electrolyte (33.2 vs. 57.2 nm). XPS survey was further used to analyze the chemical composition of CEI film generated in both electrolytes (Fig. 6c–e). In the eutectogel electrolyte, the signal at 293.5 eV in the C 1s spectrum is associated with CF, suggesting that LiTFSI and 3F-NMA is involved in the formation of the CEI membrane [53]. Signals of LiF (684.5 eV) and CF (688.2 eV) were clearly detected in the F 1s spectra [54]. LiF is mainly produced by the oxidative decomposition of LiTFSI or FEC. LixN-rich peaks (398.4 eV) appeared in the N 1s spectrum, which originates from the decomposition of 3F-NMA and TFSI− [2]. However, the electrode surface in the commercial electrolyte is rich in unstable reduction products of carbonates and LiPF6, contains no nitrogen and only a small amount of LiF, which is not conducive to the stability of the interface [48]. In summary, the eutectogel electrolyte can form a thin and stable LiF/LixN-rich interfacial layer on the surface of the cathode, which provides a stable electrode/electrolyte interface, thus ensuring the long-term cycling stability of the Li||LFP full cell [55]. The Li||LFP cells were further evaluated with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As shown in Fig. S12, the overall resistance of Li||LFP cell with eutectogel electrolyte remains consistent over 100 cycles. This observation suggests that a robust interfacial protective layer formed in the initial state is crucial for sustaining the long-term cycling stability of cells [56]. In contrast, the impedance of Li||LFP cell with commercial electrolyte increases significantly after 100 cycles. This indicates that the established interfacial layer is not stable enough and progressively deteriorates during cycling, thus leading to the reduced cycling stability of cells.

We also studied the performance of Li||LFP cells at an elevated temperature of 60 °C, using both eutectogel and commercial electrolytes, since the high-temperature performance of electrolytes is also an important parameter for its evaluation. At 1 C, the initial discharge capacity of the cell with eutectogel electrolyte reaches 156.1 mAh g−1. After 400 cycles, it remains at a high capacity of 128.1 mAh g−1. The measured average CE value of 99.5 % and the capacity retention rate of 82.1 % (Fig. 7 a and b) outperform the performance of the commercial electrolyte-based Li||LFP battery, which decreases to 64.2 % after only 200 cycles. Additionally, the rate performance at 60 °C further confirms the superiority of the eutectogel electrolyte-based Li||LFP cell over the commercial electrolyte-based one, showing more stable capacities and better reversibility (Fig. 7c).

Given the advantage of the broad electrochemical stability window of eutectogel electrolytes (seen in Fig. 2e), we aim to further assess the feasibility of its application in a high-voltage Li||LCO full cell. In this case, the cycling performance of Li||LCO cell was studied between 3.0 to 4.45 V at 30 °C. As depicted in Fig. 7d and Fig. S13, The Li||LCO full cell with eutectogel electrolyte exhibits a notable initial discharge capacity of 167.4 mAh g−1 and an ICE of 88.7 % at 0.1 C, maintaining 86.3 % of its initial capacity after 300 cycles and remaining a high capacity of 144.5 mAh g−1. In comparison, the battery with commercial electrolyte exhibits a capacity retention of only 32.0 % after 100 cycles, despite exhibiting a higher ICE (93.1 %). Furthermore, the rate performance of the eutectogel-based Li||LCO full cell significantly exceeds the commercial electrolyte (Fig. 7e), highlighting its potential for high-voltage battery application. Overall, compared with the commercial electrolyte, the present eutectogel electrolyte shows better thermal stability and safety, exhibits better electrochemical performance, and maintains superior cycling stability at high temperature and high voltage (Fig. 7f).

In conclusion, we have developed a novel eutcctogel electrolyte by ETPTA polymer network confined amide-based eutectic electrolyte. The electrolyte demonstrates a high lithium-ion transference number (t Li += 0.63) and good lithium-ion conductivity. The Li||Li symmetric cells assembled with the eutectogel electrolyte display stable lithium stripping/plating over 2300 and 720 h at current densities of 0.2 and 0.5 mA cm−1, respectively. Furthermore, it shows excellent long-term cycling stability when integrated into Li||LFP cells, achieving a capacity retention rate of up to 77.4 % after 1000 cycles at 5 C, along with robust electrochemical stability under elevated temperature (60 °C). Analysis of structure and composition confirms the development of LiF/LixN-rich SEI/CEI on the electrode surfaces, ensuring the batteries' outstanding cycling performance. Moreover, the wide electrochemical window of the eutectogel electrolyte supports its utilization in a high-voltage Li||LCO cell, demonstrating the feasibility of the present eutectogel electrolyte in practical applications. The innovative eutectogel electrolyte reported in this study provides new insights for the design of safe and high-performance lithium metal batteries.
